title: News regarding RockMining
story_body:
RockMining Appoints New VP of Operations, Plans Industry Conference Participation

RockMining Corp. (NYSE: ROCK) announced today the appointment of Sarah Chen as Vice President of Operations, effective November 1. Chen, who previously served as Senior Director of Mine Planning at the company, will oversee operational efficiency initiatives across RockMining's North American facilities.

"Sarah brings 15 years of mining industry experience to this role," said CEO Michael Torres in a statement. "Her track record in optimizing extraction processes aligns with our operational goals for 2024."

Chen replaces David Martinez, who is transitioning to an advisory role after eight years with the company. The appointment represents an internal promotion as part of RockMining's regular succession planning process.

The company also confirmed its participation in the upcoming International Mining Expo in Denver, scheduled for December 5-7. RockMining executives plan to showcase their latest mineral processing technologies and host meetings with equipment suppliers and industry partners.

"The Denver expo provides an important platform for engaging with stakeholders across the mining sector," said Chief Technology Officer James Wilson. "We look forward to demonstrating our commitment to operational excellence."

In a separate development, RockMining launched a new digital marketing campaign titled "Mining for Tomorrow" aimed at highlighting career opportunities within the industry. The initiative includes social media outreach and partnerships with technical colleges in mining regions.

Additionally, the company announced a pilot program to reduce water consumption at its Arizona facility by 10% over the next 18 months. The initiative involves installing water recycling systems in ore processing areas and represents part of RockMining's broader environmental management strategy.

"Water conservation remains a priority in our desert operations," noted Environmental Manager Lisa Park. "This pilot program will help us evaluate technologies for potential deployment across other sites."

RockMining operates copper and gold mines in Nevada, Arizona, and British Columbia. The company reported revenues of $1.2 billion in its most recent fiscal year.

Shares of ROCK closed at $47.32 yesterday, down 0.3% in regular trading. The stock has traded between $42 and $54 over the past 12 months.
